Deputy party leader Nigel Dodds MP received confirmation from the Prime Minister that there would be no internal borders within the UK as a result of Brexit. 

Mr Dodds said, "This is a clear commitment from the Prime Minister, one which First Minister Arlene Foster indicated would be the case. There can be no question that the rights of British citizens to travel within the UK will not be affected by Brexit, and I am very glad that the PM has reiterated that this is indeed the case.

An Irish Sea border artificially splitting the UK was something which many remoaners were keen to flag up as an issue which would affect Northern Ireland. However today we have seen that First Minister Rt Hon Arlene Foster has been on the right side of the argument on our borders and that our voice has been heard.

From the very beginning we said that we did not expect to see a hard border with the Republic, still less, any sort of border within the UK. News that there will not be any de-facto borders should put any fear-mongering to bed."

The North Belfast MP continued, "While there rightly won't be a running commentary on the Brexit negotiations, it will be noted that this is an aspect which the Prime Minister has been willing to give her clear, public commitment on.

"While others want to just talk about the Brexit, the DUP at Westminster and Stormont is doing and delivering. We, like the Prime Minister, are committed to getting the best deal for Northern Ireland and the UK as a whole."

The DUP are delighted to welcome Limavady Cllr Aaron Callan to the party. This party is committed to building a stronger, better Northern Ireland and Cllr Callan will continue to hold fast to this on the Causeway Coast and Glens Council. 

Welcoming Cllr Callan to the party DUP Leader and First Minister Rt Hon Arlene Foster MLA said, "I want to warmly welcome Cllr Aaron Callan to the ranks of the Democratic Unionist Party.  He is a talented and enthusiastic public representative who cares deeply about his local area.   As a Councillor on the Causeway Coast and Glens Council Aaron will fit in well with our strong team in East Londonderry led by Gregory Campbell MP.  
 
I commend Aaron for making this move at this time and I assure him that he will have a full role to play as we build a stronger Northern Ireland.  Aaron's move is yet another indication that the DUP is now the only unionist party that is capable of commanding support across the Province.  Many from an Ulster Unionist background are uniting around the DUP and have already joined with us since the Assembly election and I know Aaron will not be the last."

status_message: Congratulations to First Minister for Northern Ireland Rt Hon Arlene Foster MLA, who was admitted into the Privy Council this evening at Buckingham Palace by Her Majesty the Queen.

First Minister Arlene Foster has expressed sympathy on the death of Orange Order Grand Secretary Drew Nelson. 

She said, "The news of Drew's passing is so very difficult to take in. Even though we knew he was courageously battling his illness, it is still so final to hear that he has passed away. His death will be deeply felt right across the Orange Order fraternity and throughout Northern Ireland this morning. 

I have known Drew for many years. He was a dear friend and I and many like me will miss his wise counsel. 

He was a towering figure in the Orange Order, doing so much to contribute to its ideals and its reputation. His commitment to the principals of the organisation was something that was widely admired.

He fought his illness with tremendous courage and fortitude, and today my thoughts are with his mother, sister in law and nephews as they come to terms with this huge loss."

Paul Givan has welcomed the announcement today that the iconic 'Weeping Window' sculpture will be displayed at the Ulster Museum next year. 

The installation was originally at HM Tower of London in 2014 marking the anniversary of the outbreak of World War 1 and will be on display in locations across the UK until 2018.

status_message:
We're delighted that Ards and North Down Councilor Daniel Allen has decided to join the DUP. 

Party Leader Arlene Foster welcomed him, "Daniel is an excellent public representative and I am delighted that he has decided to join the DUP. Daniel already works closely with our Party group on the Council and I know he will make a very valuable contribution and find himself at home in the DUP. 

As I speak to people right across Northern Ireland I am heartened by their support and this is not the last such announcement that I will have the pleasure of making. Announcements relating to further recruits will be made in due course."

Cllr Allen said, "I am delighted to be joining the Democratic Unionist Party. 

Under the leadership of Arlene Foster I believe Unionism will be stronger and will dominate the political landscape in Northern Ireland for many years ahead. 

The DUP has assembled a strong and united group which have been endorsed by the electorate in recent May elections. 

The next 5 years will be a testing time and I look forward to help taking on the challenge with my new party."

Gregory Campbell has welcomed the announcement this evening that next year's Irish Open will be coming to Portstewart Golf Club.
(Pictured is Arlene Foster with Rory McIlroy when the competition was held at Royal Portrush back in 2012)

Mr Campbell said, 'This is fantastic news, not just for the Causeway Coast area but the whole of Northern Ireland, as the competition will again bring visitors and publicity to the area. Northern Ireland is becoming renowned across the world amongst golf tourists, with Portstewart and Portrush offering some of the finest courses anywhere in the world.
 
This competition is the latest in a long line of major events to come to Northern Ireland and I would pay tribute to the work carried out by the First Minister, successive Economy Ministers, and Rory McIlroy in their role in continuing to ensure that a positive image of Northern Ireland is promoted across the world.

I will continue to work to ensure that Portstewart and the wider area is ready to maximise the benefits from hosting the competition which hopefully will be as popular as it was in Portrush back in 2012.'

Musical Instruments for Bands funding to be reinstated
 
Minister for Communities, Paul Givan MLA, has told the Newsletter that the Musical Instruments for Bands funding will be reinstated. £200,000 of funding will be available for bands across Northern Ireland in 2016/17.
 
The programme, which is distributed through the Arts Council provides grants from £500 to £5,000 for the purchase of instruments to bands based in Northern Ireland which are formally constituted and who have not received a grant from the fund in the previous five years. It is generally accessed by the marching bands community.
 
The Minister said: "It was very disappointing for many bands when this programme was suspended last year by the DCAL Minister Caral Ni Chuilin. Whilst the total amount of money available is relatively modest it is still a very important funding source for bands.    
 
The marching bands sector is the largest community arts sector in Northern Ireland with nearly 30,000 people regularly participating in over 600 bands. A huge effort is put in by volunteers who contribute not just musically and culturally but economically. The £200,000 funding provided within the scheme is part of over £1million spent each year on musical instruments alone.Bands also provide structure, discipline and a social outlet for thousands of young people across the Province and I will continue to work to ensure that adequate resources are available for the sector.
 
Bands from every corner of the Province have benefitted from the funding from inner city areas to more isolated rural communities. Our parading culture has been described as "Northern Ireland's best kept secret" and I want to help support and promote it. Over the next few days people across the Province will be able witness the quality of musical talent we have in Northern Ireland. We have pipe, silver, flute and accordion bands which are amongst the best in the world and the vast majority of these will be performing on our streets this week." 

Since 2011, £200,000 has been allocated each year to the Arts Council for the Musical Instruments for Bands Scheme.

status_message:
Foster meets with Kingsmills families

 

DUP Leader Arlene Foster today met with families of those murdered in the Kingsmills massacre. This follows the reopening of a criminal investigation into the sectarian murder of the ten Protestant workmen in 1976.

 

Speaking afterwards Arlene Foster said, 'In common with so many of those who suffered at the hands of terrorism in Northern Ireland, the Kingmills families want truth and justice for their loved ones.

 

Whilst they reopening of the criminal investigation has raised questions in some minds about how this evidence has only come forward now, it does bring open the possibility that someone might finally be held responsible for this heinous crime. That hope of justice is something the Kingsmills families share with many others.

 

I would hope that the investigation can now move swiftly and the families would at least see some level of justice served.'

 

Local MLA William Irwin said, 'Having attended the service in Bessbrook in January, I am glad the First Minister was able to meet with the families again today. There are obviously many mixed emotions following the events of the last few days, but it is important that we stand in solidarity with those who suffered so greatly and who have waited so long for justice.

 

It is vital that the families are kept informed during this process so that their pain is not worsened through being kept in the dark about what is happening. Whilst we await further information about the inquest process I would hope that the criminal investigation can be seen to progress quickly.'

We're delighted to welcome Cllr Raymond Farrell to the DUP.

A thank you from the First Minister as MLAs gathered at Stormont today for the first time since the Assembly election.

We would like to thank every one of the 202,567 people who gave their first preference to a DUP candidate, and those whose later preferences help to elect 38 DUP MLAs and return Arlene Foster as Northern Ireland's First Minister.
Unionism can win in West Belfast. We can do it. Vote. Get your friends and family to vote. Vote McCoubrey 1 and transfer to other Unionists.

William Irwin was in court today along with Beatrice Worton and members of innocent victims group FAIR to support Mrs Worton's challenge against McCreesh Park. 

He said, "I want to give great credit to Mrs Worton today as she is a very strong and courageous woman who has shown such determination on this matter. I welcome the fact today leave has been granted to further pursue the horrendous decision by a local Council to name a children's play park after a dead IRA terrorist."

The second of our five key priorities is to continue creating more jobs and increase incomes.
